text: Wow hi everybody
Anthony Fantino here the Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for an
album review
this band is named cormorant and this
album is titled dwellings these guys are
a California metal band this is their
sophomore LP it's self released and this
LP is definitely a nice little surprise
gem that landed at the end of this year
because these guys have a lot that's
worth admiring they're really heavy
they're really melodic their songs are
very detail-oriented not to mention
these guys are really dynamic and how
they build their songs - there's so much
to say about this record I don't even
know where to start because as I listen
through this album every time I thought
I had cormorant kind of figured out they
pull another surprise out of their
sleeve another influence another emotion
another trick so I figure I'll just kind
of start with the the sound of this
album which is really great the
production on this thing is is killer
whether whether the band is just
shooting for these mountainous highs or
these really kind of dramatic and quiet
moons all the sounds are just really
pristine and the recording just has this
really nice mix of of clarity but also
like grit - the guitars come in really
heavy the vocals come in really raspy
and it all just sounds so live but not
that a low five recording is is bad but
I think being able to make out the bass
lines being able to take in the detail
of the guitar solos being able to hear
intelligible vocals
that have a really strong narrative all
those things just make me appreciate
this album even more the band covers a
lot of different sounds and and textures
on this album they're really booming
heavy guitar chords that worry now in a
really do me way on the second track
harmonized guitars
Lausanne unearthly dreamings there's an
instrumental track as well with these
really kind of oddly time progressive
riffs and shots of black metal blast
beats here and there too these guys
really work to blend a lot of genres
together and that to me is kind of what
their style is black metal do metal
progressive metal death metal as well on
here and it's all fed through this great
production and this really melodic
sensibility there's spots on here that
made me think of Mastodon and then these
guys would push into a different
direction and then I think of like angle
lock and then they would push into a
different direction and I think of like
Oh paths this is the sounds that
influence cormorant on this record are
pretty obvious but how they pull them
all together it's just really graceful
and that's what kind of makes this
record unique to me like the opening
chords on a howling lust which are which
are really kind of pretty and a little
funky in a way build into these really
pummeling riffs nicely the purest land
has these interjecting black metal
moments that that bring the insanity of
that track even higher and I love how
there are spots on these tracks that
kind of transition into these very kind
of post rocky and vocal samples where
you'll you'll get this big long vocal
snippet that will kind of push the
narrative of the song forward and that's
really kind of the last thing on this
record that to me makes it a pretty bold
release the narratives the tales that
are being spun into these songs some of
the lyrics on here you can follow from
the beginning to the end of a song and
really get a lot out of it if you're
listening hard enough it's almost like
these guys are composing stories as well
as songs and sometimes it's almost like
the lead singer is playing a character
in this story that he's pulling together
and a lot of these stories reflect real
life and every song has a different tale
behind it the song the purest land sort
of seems to be about this this genocide
o madman who's just like out of control
and just like is is kind of a
megalomaniac the vocals on that track
just feel noticeably crazy
than the other songs the second track on
here is actually about highwire artist
Philippe Petit and their lyrics on here
about the wire and flying and some of
the lyrics are actually in French too
the song Hunta lyrically is one of the
most specific songs on here in
atrocities that happened in Guinea not
too long ago the song unearthly
dreamings is about an astronaut who dies
in the line of duty and a howling lust
is about a lynch mob that gangs up in
and kills a Chinese man for defending
himself against someone who was trying
to hurt him all the stories on this
album deal with with death facing death
injustice and the darkness of humanity
and the songs and the emotions on this
record react to those ideas and
situations kind of tumbling back and
forth between aggression and and
melancholy I know I love what I'm
hearing but I don't feel like I want to
present understand it yet because there
are a lot of layers and there are a lot
of details to breathe in with this
record whether it be narrative lies or
whether it be musically this thing
really manages to come across as a piece
of like thinking man's metal without
being really technical or just like
enveloped and it's in its own skill it's
a great balance of story and song
there's lots of variation on here and it
all kind of comes together underneath
I guess this consistent vocal and great
production I think somebody who's really
not even into metal sometimes can get
into this record and really appreciate
the melody and the songwriting that goes
into these tracks I'm feeling a decent
eight on this record as far as negatives
go I feel like some of the tracks on
here do feel a little long-winded some
of the vocal samples here and there get
a little distracting for me and I felt
like on the instrumental track here
these guys did lose their flavor a
little bit I will say that I do think
their vocalists and just their ability
to spin these narratives is part of what
makes these guys so interesting and
original all that aside this thing is a
hell of a record
sounds like a lot went into it and
therefore I am getting a lot out of it
have you heard this thing what do you
think of it do you love it do you hate
it why and what do you think I should
review next anthony Fantino cormorant
dwellings
